message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "10/05/2005 10:02;AM;a@xyz.com;student=student1 std=X marks=87 rollnumber=102";
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input, ";");
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String date = st.nextToken();
        String ampm = st.nextToken();
        String email = st.nextToken();
        String details = st.nextToken();
        StringTokenizer stDetails = new StringTokenizer(details, " ");
        while (stDetails.hasMoreTokens()) {
            String detail = stDetails.nextToken();
            StringTokenizer stDetail = new StringTokenizer(detail, "=");
            while (stDetail.hasMoreTokens()) {
                String key = stDetail.nextToken();
                String value = stDetail.nextToken();
                System.out.println(key + " : " + value);
            }
        }
    }
}}
<<<explanation>>>: The StringTokenizer class is used to break a string into tokens. In the given code, we first tokenize the input string using ";" as the delimiter. Then for each token, we further tokenize it using " " (space) as the delimiter to get the details. For each detail, we again tokenize it using "=" as the delimiter to get the key-value pairs. This way, we can parse the file effectively. However, please note that StringTokenizer does not handle empty strings and does not distinguish between identifiers, numbers, quoted strings, etc. For more complex parsing, you might want to use regular expressions or a parser generator.
